petitioner.name: ASHBEL T. WALL, II, DIRECTOR, RHODE ISLAND DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONS

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 09-868, Wall v. Kholi. Mr. Weisman.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But, Mr. Weisman, the phrase is "post-conviction or other" -- "or other collateral review."  And certainly the Rule 25 -- 35 motion is postconviction. So it's postconviction.  It's not direct review.  Why isn't that responsive?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: "Or" usually means it's something in addition.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Can you go back to the -- you said -- you said "prior to."  I thought the Rule 35 motion is made after the conviction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But isn't that true regardless of whether the Rule 35 motion seeks legal relief or discretionary relief alone?  That both can be made prior to the finality of the judgment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And -- and if I understand your argument, your argument is that Rule 35 motions that seek legal review do fall within the 2244(d)(2) language.  It's just that Rule 35 motions that seek discretionary relief do not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Would Rule 35 permit a challenge for a Federal violation?  You've given an example of an illegal sentence that you think is discretionary; am I correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But does Rule 35(a) permit a legal challenge of the kind that Justice Kagan was asking?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right.  Let's assume a pure legal challenge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Would Rule 35(a) be other collateral relief --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- as designated by the statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So explain again why you don't think this is collateral?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No, no, no.  Why is Rule 35, assuming it's a -- a challenge to an illegal sentence on a legal ground --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why would it not be collateral review?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't -- I don't understand your argument at all.  It seems to me the phrase "post-conviction or other collateral review" means postconviction collateral review or preconviction collateral review.  Isn't that what is added? "Post-conviction or other"; what's "other" from "post-conviction"?  I guess it would be preconviction, wouldn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's fine.  And is this direct review?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So it's collateral review? So --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you lose.MR. WEISMAN:  This -- this Court, though, Your Honor, has said that, speaking about when Congress enacted 2255, it simplified the procedure for making a collateral attack on a final judgment entered in a Federal criminal case, but it did not purport to modify the distinction, again, between collateral review and direct review.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I would think that if -- if there's anything to the point you're making, it -- it hinges not on the "post-conviction or other collateral" phrase, but rather on the word "review." I suppose it could be argued that you're not reviewing the judgment if you're asking for mercy. Whether a judgment was good or bad, you're -- you're asking for mercy.  And I would -- you know, perhaps it's not review.  Is that your point?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that's only because all the cases we've had involved that.  We've never had a case like this before.  So in all those other cases,we've used the natural term "collateral review."  That doesn't mean it couldn't apply to this.  It just means we've never had occasion to inquire whether it applies to this.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Weisman, I think that that's not right, that the -- as you say, that the Rule 35 motion that Rhode Island has is based on the Federal Rule 35 motion that existed prior to 1987, and that on a couple of occasions this Court talked about that prior Federal Rule 35 as collateral review.  Am I wrong about that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: U.S. v. Robinson, Bartone v. United States.  And I might be wrong about it.MR. WEISMAN:  We don't believe it ever referred to a sentence -- a plea for sentence leniency, Your Honor, no, not -- not as a plea, a pure plea for leniency under Rule 35.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And the current Federal rule --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- provides for -- it's Rule 35 also, but it doesn't have the pure leniency? That's Rhode Island's?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Let's assume that we adopt your formulation generally, that it has to be for legal error, collateral review has to be for legal error, and we could even add what the Ninth Circuit has found, it has to be by a court in order to avoid clemency, parole review boards, and so forth. I don't see why you don't lose anyway, because the allegation here, the complaint, the argument, may be that there was an abuse of discretion, and if there's an abuse of discretion, that is a legal ground to set aside the -- the sentence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, it's a motion made in a court, reviewable by the appellate courts of the State.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It's a little odd to say that that's not legal.  If -- an abuse of discretion standard is something we're quite familiar with in the law.  We've never thought of that as being somehow extra-legal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And if there's no justification, what do they do?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Are those different than the characteristics that the sentencing judge looks at in the first instance?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: In other words, how these -- you've obviously seen a lot of these, and I haven't seen any, but I mean, do the Rule 35 motions typically say -- do they typically concede the legal validity of the sentence and then simply say -- what? mean, I assume the sentencing is -- is completely open and you can put in anything at all, like the -- the deprived childhood, the unique situation, the age, whatever.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: In what sense is Rule 35 different from the arguments that are made at sentencing?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that's bad for you, isn't it, I mean for the very point that Justice Kennedy was raising?  If it's the same sort of arguments that you get to raise as a legal matter prior to the imposition of sentencing, why should they not be considered legal matters when they're raised under Rule 35?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Are those issues that can be -- that are typically raised on direct -- direct review?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Do you quarrel with a statement in Mollicone, a Rhode Island 2000 decision that says we will interfere with the trial court'sdiscretion, vis-Ã -vis sentencing, only in rare instances where the trial justice has imposed a sentence that is without justification and is grossly disparate from the other sentences generally imposed for similar offenses?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Is that the review standard?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That is the standard of review, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So please explain to me why that is not what Justice Kennedy described as a review for abuse of discretion and why a review for abuse of discretion is not a legal challenge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  Am Imisunderstanding you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Are you saying that the Rhode Island appellate courts never change a sentence under Rule 35?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Or are you saying that they do find some lack of justification in some sentences?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, then -- then think you're saying that it only gets reversed for abuse of discretion, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that's a legal ground, it seems to me.  And I don't know how you could say that that's a plea for leniency.  It's a plea that -- that the sentencing court abused its discretion and should have given a lesser sentence.  How is that leniency? It's abuse of discretion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't want to have to figure this out case by case, or even jurisdiction by jurisdiction, as to whether it's an abuse of discretion review or a leniency review or this or that.  And that -- that makes me inclined to say we should treat your Rule 35 as coming within the tolling provision, so we don't have to grapple with -- I mean, I'm not having very much success understanding the distinction that you're telling me.  I don't want to have to do this for 50 States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Can you read the -- the relevant provision of the Rule 35?  I mean, there are two categories, the ones about legal challenges, at least as I read the rule, and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So you're talking about reducing --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Weisman, I'm sorry. Before you talk about policy, so this motion to reduce sentence is very short.  It just says that the man "prays that the sentence imposed with respect to the above matter be reduced in accordance with the provisions of Rule 35."  Would it make a difference to you if it said he prays that the sentence imposed -- he prays that the illegal sentence imposed with respect to the above matter be reduced in accordance with provisions of Rule 35?MR. WEISMAN:  It might be.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: If he had put in that word, "illegal," would that have made the difference?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So -- but that does suggest the difficulty that Justice Scalia raises, is that we're going to have to look at the particular rule of the State, we're going to have to look at the particular motion, we're going to look at any -- we're going to have to look at any State law regarding how motions are construed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And this is going to be a very difficult determination.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So a petitioner in the future in Rhode Island should file a petition that says: I'm filing a motion pursuant to 35(a) for an illegal sentence -- make something up --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- or for leniency.  And then are district courts supposed to figure out whetherthe legal challenge was frivolous or not or had a basis in law or fact --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- and then decide whether they would toll or not toll based on that now side trial on what's an illegal sentence and what's just a plea for leniency?  That's what you are proposing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So what if they say "correct the illegal sentence because it was an abuse of discretion"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So is the magic words "illegal sentence" or is the magic words "abuse of" -- what are the magic words?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Either -- either yourvictory will give you absolutely nothing, or you have truly stupid defendant lawyers in Rhode Island.  I mean, why would anybody not caption the 35 motion that way?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What's to lose?  You say it doesn't matter if your claim of an illegal sentence is frivolous or not.  What's to lose?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: There is another argument that you could make, other than the one you've been pressing, which is that collateral review means something other than a step in the criminal case.  But you've chosen not to make that; is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you've said that thiscould be done before finality.  I thought -- I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm sure you said that earlier, that this motion can be made before the judgment is final.  Didn't you say that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But that's not what you just said.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What you just said is after the finality.  Which is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  I'm not sure I understand that.  There's nothing in this rule that bars a litigant from filing after the conviction is final.  They have 120 days.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Justice Scalia's suggestion --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Except that it says --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- that perhaps the -- the leniency review is -- is not review of the conviction or sentence.  But you didn't -- you didn't do anything with that.  You didn't argue that the kind of review that's involved with leniency is really not review of the sentence for legal error.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So what -- is itsomething in between?  It's not direct and it's not collateral?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What about a motion --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I guess we need a new adjective then, because I'd always thought that there are two kinds of review, direct and collateral.  You say there's a -- a tertium quid.  What do you want us to call that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think that maybe it doesn't need to be called anything because it doesn't exist.  I -- I can't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- imagine anything thatisn't either direct or collateral.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But, Mr. Weisman, that's true also of State habeas claims that are based only on State law.  But six circuits have said that 2244(d)(2) applies to those claims.  Are you contesting that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Where the exhaustion policy does not come into effect.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Ms. Mizner.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Am I correct that you think "post-conviction or other collateral review" means anything that occurs after the conclusion of direct review?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Then what does the phrase "or other collateral review" add?  Why -- why wouldn't Congress just say "post-conviction review"?MS. MIZNER:  In Duncan, this Court talked about the possibility of civil commitment or contempt in custody that could be part of the Rule 2254 proceeding and that that would not be postconviction.  So that postconviction is a form of collateral review but is not the only form. In Duncan, the Court also discussed the fact that many States may call what other States call "post-conviction review" something else, and that that would also then be collateral.  The collateral is just a -- an umbrella that encompasses postconviction and other forms of review after a judgment.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why don't you just call your motion a motion to correct an illegal sentence?  Then we wouldn't have any dispute here, I gather.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You're not one of the stupid lawyers that we were worried about before. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sure of that. But you do think that if you had -- if you or whoeverfiles these motions had simply said that, there would be no problem, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, it's because you want something other than legal review, right?  You want to throw yourself on the mercy of the court. You've got plenty of avenues to correct the illegality of the sentence, but this is something different, right? This is to -- not correct -- you admit it's illegal, but you say but it should still be reduced for a lot of reasons.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You can raise all of those -- all of those claims under the normal State collateral postconviction, State habeas, all those other things, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So I guess I'm having trouble.  You can -- the various grounds on which the sentence should have been lower than it was, including the fact that setting the sentence at that level was an abuse of discretion, you obviously can raise those at sentencing and you can raise those on direct review, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Can you challenge it on -- in State habeas?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That's the only vehicle you have --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It's the only vehicle you have for challenging the sentence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So after a conviction in the State, if there's an appeal with a number -- on direct review, with a number of issues, improperly admitted evidence and so forth, you -- the lawyer can't add:  And, in addition, he was sentenced under the wrong provision; he was given 5 years too many because the judge cited the wrong provision.  You can't say that on direct review?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You can challenge only the conviction, not the sentence, on direct review?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE
speakers.text: In what --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do you agree that Rule 35 is not something that the prisoner must exhaust before seeking Federal habeas?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But this is the whole purpose of allowing tolling of the 1-year Federal statute, the purpose to give the petitioner an opportunity to exhaust what he must exhaust?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I -- I may have asked this already, but it seems unusual to me so I want to make sure of the answer.  Your -- you have a client who is convicted of a particular offense that results ina sentence of, what, zero to 5 years, okay?  And the judge, in imposing the sentence, engages in racial discrimination.  It turns out that he sentences African-Americans to 5 years and Caucasian defendants to 2 years.  That, you're telling me, is a claim that you cannot raise on direct review or on -- in State habeas?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, you say it "would be raised."  Are you saying it can only be raised under Rule 35?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That's what I would have thought.  So Rule 35 is not the only vehicle for challenging a sentence?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I -- your adversary said the contrary, and I was -- you're flip-flopping.  Can this be brought on a direct appeal or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: A non-legal sentence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So what did you meanwhen you answered the Chief Justice that it could be brought in collateral proceedings?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Just so your adversary, when he gets up on rebuttal, can confirm or not this point, any challenge to an illegal sentence has to be brought first in a Rule 35(a) motion, regardless of what the grounds of the illegality are?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Can I return to the question Justice Ginsburg asked a couple of minutes ago?  We have -- let's say we have a case in which a defendant convicted in State court has some exhausted Federal claims that this defendant wants to raise in a Federal habeas; also files a motion seeking a reduction of sentence based purely on a request for leniency, a sentence within the range prescribed by the statute. What purpose is served by tolling the time to file the Federal habeas during the pendency of this request for leniency in the State court?  Now, you say comity, but in concrete practical terms, what purpose is served?MS. MIZNER:  A prisoner who receives adequate relief in the State court, through whatever vehicle, may choose not to pursue a Federal habeas corpus claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: In your experience, does that happen a lot?  You have somebody who is sentenced to a 5-year sentence and that's within the range, also has legal challenges that would result in no conviction, no time whatsoever and no criminal conviction -- that person decides to give up on the legal challenge because the 5-year sentence might be reduced to 3 or 2 or 1?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Can you explain --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If you look at 2255 -- that's the Federal postconviction review, and it also has a 1-year statute of limitations.  That limitation would not be tolled for a Federal Rule 35 motion.  So why should it be tolled for State?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I think, Ms. Mizner, the amicus brief in this case asserted that, in Rhode Island or in other States with a rule like this, many judges sit on these Rule 35 motions.  They just let them stay pending for a considerable period of time, in order to retain some ability to modify the sentence if and when they feel like doing so.  Is that your understanding of what happens to these motions, that they just sit, that they are not denied?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I guess the question -- and I'm sorry if I cut you off -- is not that this is a question of abuse, that it may be a good thing.  The idea is you've got a motion for reduction of sentence because of mercy, and the judge might say: Well, I'm inclined to exercise mercy if you come out of the rehab program in a good way, if it turns out afterthe first several months that you're a model prisoner. In other words, it's not a question of abuse, it's a good thing; and if we start saying that the time for Federal habeas is tolled, judges might be inclined not to exercise such charity based on the prisoner's conduct after conviction.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: 120 days, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: For filing?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do we have any indication in the case law what a reasonable time consists of?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Can you go back for a second?  Imagine a defendant is convicted of robbery and he's sentenced to 10 years.  He thinks there is an errorin my conviction of a legal nature, and he thinks there is another error in my -- in my sentence of a legal nature.  Now, I take it in Rhode Island he files an appeal to consider the first.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And as to the second, he files a Rule 35 motion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And when does he file the Rule 35 motion?  Because it says at any time.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, it doesn't say that. It says a court may correct an illegal sentence "at any time."  I'm talking --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It has nothing to do with mercy.  I want to know how it works.  He says there's a legal error in my sentence.  When -- how does he get that corrected?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I have -- I'm not -- don't take what I have as my view.  I just want the fact.  I'masking you a fact.  When -- how and when does the person correct the legal error in his sentence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Where?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And if the trial court says no, what does he do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Fine.  Okay.  So now we have two appeals.  One is from the judgment of conviction; another is from the judgment imposing the sentence.  Now, the Federal statute says a 1-year period of limitation shall apply from the date on which the judgment became final.  Correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  When is the date on which the judgment of the sentence became final?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And if they are not appealing -- they are not -- they are not at the same time, then what?MS. MIZNER:  Then the judgment would become final when the Rhode Island Supreme Court affirmed the conviction and either this Court --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why not the sentence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: In April, they affirm the conviction.  In June, they affirm the sentence.  Do those 2 months -- does the date on which the judgment became final by conclusion of direct review, does that run from April or from June?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: June.  Okay.  Now, suppose he doesn't -- suppose that there were no appeal from the -- I see.  Our problem is that there is no appeal from the judgment -- from the sentence where he asks for correction as a matter of mercy and not law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: There may be?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What I'm trying to figure out is why, if you're willing to call, for purposes of one -- the 1-year statute begins to run from the time the direct appeal becomes final.  Why is it a direct appeal of a sentence where you appeal the matter of lawand it isn't a direct appeal of a sentence where you ask for mercy?  It's the same rule.  It's the same procedure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: This would help you just as much, I imagine.  I'm just trying to get it straight in my mind.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know.  You see, my basic question is:  Why -- look, two appeals; one judgment, one sentence.  Okay?  January, June. You're prepared to say the 1-year statute does not begin to -- to run until June.  Fine.  The Rule 35 motion, when you took an appeal, became final for purposes of the Federal habeas statute in June. So why doesn't the Rule 35 motion become final under (1)(a) of the habeas statute, whenever that's decided finally?  Why is it collateral at all? Why isn't it direct, just as your first one was direct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Wait a minute.  Judgment ofwhat?  Judgment of conviction --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- or judgment of sentence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's not the same reason that it doesn't become final when you haven't appealed your sentence yet, or when they haven't -- they didn't consolidate. I am quite confused, as you see, as to how this all works in Rhode Island.  I -- Rhode Island -- I used to be on the First Circuit.  I know it has some special ways of doing things that are sometimes different, and this is different.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: There must be in Rhode Island some complaints about the sentence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Both.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What would happen if the statutory maximum for an offense in Rhode Island is 5 years and the sentencing judge imposes a sentence of 10 years, and the defense attorney at that time says, well, you can't do that, that's more than a statutory maximum; and the judge goes ahead with it, and then an appeal is taken? You're saying that the appellate court in Rhode Island would not entertain that argument?  They would say you have to go back and make a Rule 35 motion in the trial court?  Maybe that's the procedure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: It seems odd.  Is that it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is there a citation for that, that you have?  Is it your --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Could I return you to something more basic?  Do you think the term "collateral review" is a legal term of art, or is it a term that we can -- we should interpret simply by looking up the word "collateral" in a dictionary?MS. MIZNER:  Well, this Court has discussed the -- has used the term "collateral review" in a -- a number of different contexts, in civil cases, in habeas cases, in the -- in the manner of distinguishing between direct review and something that is outside direct review.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Isn't -- if I look up "collateral attack" in Black's Law Dictionary, won't I find a definition there?  And won't it tell me that this is something other than the proceeding?  This is an attack on a judgment outside of the proceeding that led to the entry of that judgment.  Isn't that what the term generally means?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But it's part of the case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, what about just a regular motion for a new trial, not based on newly -- on newly discovered evidence?  Is that collateral, or is -- is that part of the -- the criminal proceeding?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, what's wrong with the argument that nothing that occurs in the criminal case itself is collateral?  What Congress had in mind when it spoke about collateral review was something like habeas. Let me give you an alternative interpretation of this, and maybe it's completely wrong, but you'll tell me why it's wrong. "Post-conviction" is a term of art.  Many States, including Rhode Island, have postconviction review statutes.  So Congress wanted to have that time, the time when those proceedings were tolled -- were pending tolled.  But not every State uses that phrase. Not every State uses that term.  They have other namesfor the proceeding, and that's what's meant by "other collateral review."  "Collateral review" is a term of art.  It's not something that you understand by looking up the word "collateral" in a dictionary. What's wrong with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I'm not saying it has to do with whether it's legal or something else.  It has to do with whether it's in the criminal case or not in the criminal case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Do you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: 2255 is -- is in the original case, but it's a habeas substitute.  It was adopted by Congress as a substitute for habeas; isn't that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Do you think that a petition for clemency that's presented to the governor would toll the limitations period?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Why -- why is that different?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that may be right, but I don't think that's the reason.  I -- I thought we had held that the word "filed" in the petition means filed in a court, not filed with the governor.  It's -- it's the word "filed" in -- in the tolling provision that -- that does the work.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You think it doesn't matter that -- I mean, a Rule 35 motion is a motion made in the original criminal proceeding, not to the side of it.  So isn't a collateral attack a sort of -- another proceeding to the side of the main proceeding, but the Rule 35 motion is filed in the criminal proceeding itself?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So if this was -- if this motion had been filed before judgment, which can happen, before the judgment is final, then there would be no tolling?MS. MIZNER:  Tolling would not come into -- into play until after the judgment has become final.  If this has been addressed and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So the question --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So the answer is yes.  This motion which can be filed either before or after judgment -- the time is tolled if it's made after the judgment but not if it's made before.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: There seems to be some confusion.  Judgment is rendered before this motion is made.  There's a conviction and there's a sentence, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So there's a judgment rendered.  That's different from whether the judgment is final in a Federal sense.  It's final as far as the State is concerned, because the judgment was rendered, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: As far as the State is concerned.  If there is an appeal, then it may undo that, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So there is a judgment, and this is always post-judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well -- well, that's not -- that's not what the State says, anyway.  The State says, and I think the way 35 reads, it doesn't have to be filed after judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's right.  It can't be filed any later than that.  But it doesn't say that it can't be filed before judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: When does -- when does it become final?  When does the -- even at the trial courtlevel, when does it become final?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Weisman, you have 6 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry, I -- you were speaking so fast, I didn't follow you.MR. WEISMAN:  I'm sorry, Justice Sotomayor.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Perhaps we can go back to the simple question, which is, can a defendant who has been sentenced bring a challenge to a sentence in a direct appeal or not?  Or do they have to go by Rule 35(a)?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right.  So now we get to the point where some can go under 35(a) but some can't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So they should go on direct appeal, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's called "it'sillegal."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So now it's illegal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the odd thing is that -- that kind of appeal takes place either days or possibly weeks after the defendant may already have appealed his conviction to the higher court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That normally happens?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And what I'm curious about is what happens if the court affirms that sentence, let's say 2 months after it already affirmed the conviction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Which is the judgment pursuant to which -- which is the judgment that became final by conclusion of direct review?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- the Federal statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Exactly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And that's why I don't -- that's why I am confused.  I look at the language of the Federal statute and it seems to me that this individual is not being held in custody pursuant to a judgment until that sentence is final.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the sentence is final in the lower court, but they say when the sentence is final at the conclusion of direct review in respect to that sentence, which hasn't even taken place yet.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  Then you're going to say --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- all appeals in Rhode Island from sentences -- all appeals on their lawfulness or their mercy take place under Rule 35, and all of them are collateral.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm totally confused. If this is part of the criminal proceeding, which is your position, that it's not collateral, but it's part of the proceedings, when does this proceeding become final?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That -- that truly --because -- you're -- you're --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But if the Rhode Island court has told litigants that they can't challenge some portions of an illegal sentence except by way of Rule 35, how can we call the decision on the affirmance of the conviction a final determination of the legality of the sentence?  That's contradictory.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, but that's not -- that's not what the -- what it says.  It talks about a judgment.  And a judgment in -- in other terms is usually the conviction and the sentence.  Rhode Island for its own reasons has separated the two, but --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
